The timing is still peculiar though.

I guess we will find out soon!

I still can’t figure out what they are looking to achieve with this battery day, especially during the quarter end delivery push... It’s a weird time to do a product reveal especially if production is going to be limited initially.

text: @Equity_thinker @defnotES2 Email is an open protocol, while Slack Connect and MS Teams’ version of it will be a closed one. So at scale it’s way more powerful and arguably winner-takes-all/most. Eg Bloomberg and regional messenger apps (wechat, kakao, line).

@Equity_thinker @defnotES2 Butterfield also claims it will take yrs for MS to copy it - I hope that’s the case as well but we will see. I don’t quite yet understand the technical details of why it should take so long.

I don’t think MS would mind the Outlook cannibalization. It’s just a bundle anyway.

@thechrisyared @ValueAnalyst1 @jpr007 I am talking about the early stage private funding market. And to be clear, I am saying this hydrofraud cannot be allowed to get any bigger. If the promoters get away with this, it will lead to dozens of similarly brazen frauds
@defnotES2 There’s also some potential of there being two separate and sustainable networks as a steady state, but I am not sure.

People seem to think GM “invested” in Nikola today.

Actually, GM got 11% of Nikola equity for *free* AND got a supply contract.

Imagine giving away 11% of your company to your supplier just for the privilege of being allowed to buy overpriced parts from them

urls.title: Diecast 1:24 Scale Tesla Semi
urls.description: The Tesla Semi diecast scale model was officially commissioned by Tesla and meticulously overseen by the Tesla Design Team in California. The same 3D CAD data used to manufacture the actual Tesla Semi was used to replicate every detail, curve and surface found in the scale model. Product details: Dimensions: 292mm long x 124mm wide x 172mm high Weight: 1.48kg (3.3lb) Sold exclusively through Tesla. Shipping available to US and Canada only. WARNING: CHOKING HAZARD. Contains small parts. Not suitable for children under 14 years old.

@Aceinmysleeve1 @munster_gene Then there should be focus on total subs, not sub net adds. E.g. companies often get judged on rev beats/misses, not quarterly revenue addition beats/misses.

@Aceinmysleeve1 @munster_gene People can just use the available info and forecast Q2 revenue. Still a non-event especially for a stock that’s up so much ytd. Using quarterly net adds as headline metric just optically exaggerates beats/misses

@mingcalls But if the point is one needs to look at EBIT for Netflix, sure, that works too. Certainly better than this net add beat vs miss game. It’s not really trading on profit multiples yet though.

text: @tslaqpodcast @BradMunchen They are at 0.5% global market share and have just 3 products in the auto division. Absolutely the wrong time to worry about their growth runway.
@tslaqpodcast @BradMunchen They already told you last quarter. You didn't listen and the stock went up 100%+.

@tslaqpodcast @BradMunchen Their revenue growth in 2012Q2 was -54%. Your short position if initiated at that time would have lost 600% a year later, when the growth rate went to +1971%. What is your point?
@BradMunchen TSLA grew far faster but required more capital, for obvious reasons. Going forward they will be entirely self-financed, and growth is about to accelerate massively.
@AlternateJones Excellent summary!

@BradMunchen Sounds like a familar short thesis on AMZN when it was at $200/share.

You should look at more growth companies. You seem to not understand how growth impacts multiples.

Appendix:

I should mention that this gap vs. historical avg multiple for $TSLA is even clearer when looked at on Trailing 12 Mo Revenue basis. When analysts finally wake up & update their 2020 revenue estimates, the two charts should look similar.

It's still very early days. https://t.co/b4mbGjLN1y

text:
Note the TSLA chart above overstates the current multiple, as it is based on consensus revenue, which is too low. The real multiple today is likely <3.0x.

Summary: TSLA longs have a good chance of benefiting from multiple expansion, on top of 40-50% rev growth/yr tailwind.

5/5

Key to the applicability of this analysis is whether the growth runway remains long.

For @Tesla, the answer is absolutely: its global mkt share is still ~0.50%.

In addition, the company is closer than ever to solving autonomy and is about to accelerate its Energy business.

4/5

text: @bizruptive Long-term plays?

@gwestr The idea of testing AVs “driverless” right now is retarded. Why do that when the tech isn’t fully ready? Companies do it so that they can report numbers to the DMV and fake it to the likes of Navigant Research and VCs.

@gwestr Release this yr nationwide in the US, still requiring supervision, followed by other mkts. Then march of 9’s.

Likely validating in CA. They aren’t required to report because it’s not “driverless”.

@CraigBonthron @elonmusk It’s hard to put a number on it.

I think it’s higher than people think, because most assume that autonomy has to be “perfect”.

But in reality, it just has to be better than humans.

And it may turn out that it is a lower bar than most believe. ie humans are terrible drivers.

text: @teslanalyst Yup. It's clearly binary, but if they do solve autonomy, not hard to see these numbers be conservative. Key is how long it takes for competitors to catch up & scale their fleet.
@Starlight_Energ Yes - just needs an IRR. Which is embedded in the discount rate for the NPV. Low double digit IRR probably clears it.
@1stPrincipleInv Same here haha. Been out of school too long

@value_invest12 Actually that's exactly what will happen. Only the early buyers of the car will benefit from any material revenue sharing. Alternatively, the car price will approach the NPV such that a fleet buyer can only make a reasonable IRR.
@1stPrincipleInv We should talk about Kelly one of these days 😉 really getting into it

I realize all of this sounds insane, but it's just math.

Of course, this hinges on whether Tesla can solve autonomy.

But if they do, it's easy to see why Tesla has a good shot at becoming the most valuable company on Earth.

5/5

@ReflexFunds Hmm... for example,

A buys option 1, no delta hedging
B sells option 1, buys option 2 to hedge
C sells option 2, buys option 3 to hedge
D sells option 3, buys option 4 to hedge
E sells option 4, delta hedges with stock

@ReflexFunds For options, I think it's a bit difficult to estimate the market impact based on the open interest alone, due to desks hedging options with other options and the existence of complex position structures such as call spreads, etc.
@investesla @ericsteiman It’s a good way to put it. To be clear, this strategy only applies to a very select group of stocks. Most stocks are, unfortunately, mere vehicles for trading.

text: @trengriffin Even amazon, often cited as an example of a beneficiary of neg CCC, keeps enough cash on hand such that current assets > current liabilities.

@trengriffin This would make economic sense for early stage startups (as they have little to lose) but comes with obvious moral hazards. Established growth companies generally don’t use the cash generated from neg CCC.

@trengriffin Negative CCC is different. It would be only useful if a high growth company decided to actually use that cash, in exchange for a greater risk of going BK if the company has a year where revenues shrink significantly.
@trengriffin Positive CCC is a real problem for growth companies, because they have no choice but to fund the NWC with equity & debt.
@trengriffin Rather, negative CCC might be relevant because it is mildly correlated with the leverage a company has with its suppliers & customers.

@trengriffin I think negative CCC sounds great in theory but practicality is questionable. It is only relevant for high growth companies, and even then, it would be imprudent for such companies to spend the cash generated from NWC.
@tesla_truth every point here is pretty much spot-on
@moez #3 would be the critical step to getting there

text: @ValueAnalyst1 I am guessing you are wondering why Tesla still has a 2 week delivery estimate for M3.. But I think everything is fine. Direction of normalized order rate is far more important. And that doesn't even matter compared to Model Y and China. And everything pales in comparison to FSD.

@ValueAnalyst1 "what we saw on February 28 when we launched the standard range, the standard range plus variants is that, there is pent-up demand for those products that released very quickly after it was announced. And then, as more time has passed order rates have stabilized"
@ValueAnalyst1 I'd be pretty ecstatic to see my guess on the Q2 US M3 orders be way too conservative... But Zach said this on Q1 call:

@ValueAnalyst1 Hmm... But the pent-up SR orders came in March. I was referring to orders received in Q2. Also, I think that while steady state SR/SR+ demand may indeed be higher than LR/P, people didn't have that choice last year... So many people just pulled the trigger on LR/MR. Hard to wait.
@ValueAnalyst1 And right now it seems that "normalized" demand is rising at a satisfactory pace. So if that goes to 100K/Q in the US in a few quarters, wouldn't surprise me.

@ValueAnalyst1 Because backlog/pent-up demand was so high last year. There's nothing wrong happening - there's a "normalized" demand which goes up and down based on fundamentals, and there are temporary spikes/drops in orders depending on new variants, subsidy changes, etc which adds noise.

text: @nathan_chem @28delayslater @bonnienorman @Gfilche @AndreaSJames Price point awareness is key. Based on our survey work, most people in the US are completely unaware. Will post data later today.

@SmartishLoser I think the company expected that this architecture change would increase demand in S/X in Feb/March, but it was ultimately ineffective, in part due to everyone expecting a refresh and the pull forward into Q4.

@SmartishLoser This led them to take some emergency measures such as price changes globally in March. Logistics ended up ultimately being fine, but this had a big impact on profitability. In addition, they made some changes to the S/X price architecture on Jan 29.

@SmartishLoser @elonmusk @Tesla On why they didn’t see this coming in late Jan: there were two issues. They faced serious logistics problems this Q (Eg Belgium, where the port is located, went on strike) and they faced a situation where, worst case, delivery volumes could have been even lower by ~20K (!)
